article:
The vast majority of states in the United States employ a system of 'recording'
legal instruments that affect the title of real estate as the exclusive means
for publicly documenting land titles and interests. This system differs
significantly from land registration systems, such as the Torrens System that
have been adopted in a few states. The principal difference is that the
recording system does not determine who owns the title or interest involved.
That determination is ultimately made through litigation in the courts. What the
system does do is to provide framework for determining whom the law will protect
with relation to those titles and interests when a dispute arises.
